posts.text: Heavy Games on Your TableDecember, 2017 The term "Heavy Game" can cover a wide variety of titles. Generally, games featured on these lists are complex Eurogames, 18xx, wargames, and other games that require a significant investment in time or thought. Please post entries only for games that you have actually played this month, and include a description of the session, interesting things of note, photos, analysis, etc! The list is designed for more in-depth discussion of heavy games. Please subscribe to this thread to be notified when a new GeekList is posted each month! If the games on this list interest you, please consider joining the heavy game discussions in the following guilds:Heavy Cardboard's Podcast and videos are also great resources.And if the 18XX games on this list interest you, be sure to check out:- The Dual Gauge Podcast and Guild These Podcasts and their guilds also focus on heavy games:- Punching Cardboard Podcast and Guild - The Deep End Gaming Podcast and Guild These Podcasts cover boardgames in general, but feature some heavy games content and coverage that is worth checking out:- The Good, The Board, and The Ugly Podcast and Guild - Low Player Count Podcast and Guild Please add only one entry per game. If someone else has already added a game you are playing, just add comments! After the next month's list is posted, this list will be re-sorted alphabetically to make finding games in each list quicker. Any GG donated to the list will be re-distributed to the top few contributors at the end of the month (quality, not just quantity...) Thumb the list if you like what you see! Your Tags: 1. Board Game: 18MEX [Average Rating:7.65 Overall Rank: 2873 ] The Mirror United StatesNew York I played a three player game of 18MEX this weekend for the first time against two relatively experienced players, and trounced them. I'll let one of the others describe how that went down. Needless to say, I'm happy to be in training for 1841. Lol, like I'll ever play an 18xx with 5 people at the same time. [ Community Rules ] Edited 2. Board Game: Greed Incorporated [Average Rating:7.02 Overall Rank: 1494 ] Brian SomervilleMassachusetts I've had this sitting around for a couple of years (thanks, John Rogers !), and played about a half game early on, but it hadn't hit the table since.Last night it got played by 4 people in about 3.5 hours after rules teaching. Two opponents cashed out of a first company pretty early, ~turn 3, and got out to an early lead, but the result was that I was CEOing 3 companies, which I was able to use to bleed two of them dry after massive profits on turn 5, and the 3rd on turns 6 and 7.I ended up with the last 3 gold-frame rewards and the victory. It's plausible that more careful arithmetic by my RHO might have forced a tiebreaker by making us split the last two turns' gold and silver rewards.The game is definitely interesting, and I'm pretty sure it's a good game on top of that. I'm less sure that it's a game I enjoy - it seems that the "right" way to play it is very careful analysis of negotiations, and that's a very very slow process. I'd cheerfully play it a few more times soon to be sure. View Previous {{limitCount(numprevitems_calculated,commentParams.showcount)}} 1 « Pg. {{commentParams.pageid}} » {{data.config.endpage}} {{error.message}} [ Show Hide ] Thank you for helping us moderate the site. [ Community Rules ] Edited 3. Board Game: 1899 [Average Rating:6.43 Overall Rank: 8741 ] Dual Gauge ( DualGauge ) This 18xx game is in the vein of 1830 like games. It includes a few McGuffins - mail routes, a long distance run to Mongolia where you count up how many spots you “can” reach to the off-board location, etc. He map consists of expensive terrain costs almost covering the entire board. This is mitigated by the mail routes which pay half the starting and ending cities value into the companies treasury for a single train. Fun game, still has the feel of 1830, except longer (17,000 bank). I was out of the game after the 6’s broke and cruised to a 4th out of 5. One player went with a brown strategy which might have paid out if we would have had another set of ORs. Good change of pace from 1830 with the same feel. View Previous {{limitCount(numprevitems_calculated,commentParams.showcount)}} 1 « Pg. {{commentParams.pageid}} » {{data.config.endpage}} {{error.message}} [ Show Hide ] Thank you for helping us moderate the site. [ Community Rules ] Edited 4. Board Game: Lisboa [Average Rating:8.30 Overall Rank: 246 ] Jake Blomquist ColumbusOhio Got a three player game of this in Wednesday night. I won with a score in the 140s, both of my opponents ended in the 110s.My starting church tile gave me a discount of one public official when I opened a public building, so I decided to try opening a lot of public buildings. Both of my opponents early on got a church tile and a treasury card that increased the money they got for selling a particular good, so they both had goods selling at $9 each early on. So I picked up a church tile that gave me two extra points whenever one of my ships set sail and also two extra points per ship at end game, and I got an early level one ship. One of my opponents got the other level one ship, and so they both tried to avoid shipping with me when they could to prevent those points. By the end of the game both of us with the level one ships got level three ships as well, no one took any twos or fours. I think only once did another player fill one of my ships, but I still got about 12 points from that church tile.It took us a decent amount of time to get to the mid-game reset (though none of the card stacks were empty before the player to my right got two sets of rubble, and I got my second set the first action of the second phase). And after that I was hitting public buildings pretty often and so for a little while it looked like the game would be ending relatively early. But once I was one blue cube short of four sets I started slowing down because there was more I wanted to get done. It was definitely nice having control of when the game was ending. I ended with four rubble sets to three to two, and we emptied maybe one pile of cards but another round and we may well have emptied three and triggered the end that way.One player built a lot of pink stores in the five point column, hoping to capitalize on having the high sell value for pinks, but then he only produced twice. I think there were a total of five productions done in our game. I built a total of three stores, a blue, a brown, and a gold. There wasn't a ton of building in this game and because it was fairly focused, the worst any of my stores did was second place in the majority scoring at the end, which was nice. And I believe they each scored either 8 or 9 points from public buildings. There were enough public buildings that it was rare for a store to not score at least reasonably well.I ended up never tucking a treasury card, just because it never quite seemed ideal. I think a total of three got tucked all game (the two +$2 ones already mentioned, and one that made the blue cubes free for building stores). I had one that gave me an additional two public official discount in my hand, but by the time I got it I only had one more public building I wanted to build, enough officials already out, and some nobility cards with really strong immediate effects for when I wanted to do two minor actions that it wasn't worth it.The church track was a bit weird, with some starts and stops. Better than our last game where we got to a point with three church tiles no one wanted relatively early and then it just never moved after that. I ended up with four church tiles at one point, so I was done taking that action until we got the chance to trade them in, which finally happened fairly late. I traded in two for three points each (the starting one with the public officials discount, and one that gave me a two influence discount when visiting the king, another thing that made it easier for me to open so many public buildings), and I think everyone else gave up all of theirs at that point since it was pretty late.I think where I won the game was in the decree difference. I managed to get eight of them, and they all worked really well for what I was doing. I had a point for leftover blue goods, a point per blue rubble, and a point per red rubble which were each worth four to me, five points for having the most completed blueprints and five points for most decrees which both scored, and two points per green blueprint, two points per green public building in the north, and one point per two officials on completed blueprints which were each worth six. I think each of my opponents had maybe four decrees and scored a bit over ten each for them, so they weren't able to take as good ones as I did.I think our group tends to prioritize getting going early and worry about points later, and previously the marquis was the least visited of the main three. And the other two players in particular I think approached this game a bit more like an engine builder than they should have, thinking they were going to build a bunch of stores and produce more. This plus me getting my sets done meant I was able to get a big lead on decrees which I think was basically the difference in our scores.We also were letting each other follow more often, I remember in the past we'd been much more hesitant to visit a noble if other people (especially if at least two other people) had the appropriate king's favor. And I think we were doing it right this game, where as long as you make sure you can make good use of the secondary action it's worth it. Especially because the treasury was consistently so high.I like this game a lot. I really enjoy the central card-play mechanism as well as the way that the various systems of the game feel so interconnected. It's also really cool how different two games of this can be, just with stuff like where the treasury sits and how much the clergy moves. And the way the players determine what scores via the public buildings is a really cool twist to try to figure out.But I still think Kanban is the better game for me. Every time I've played this it just felt like I never quite had that moment of awe I get with my absolute favorite games, and I couldn't put my finger on why. On paper the game seems right up my alley, but one of the other players made an observation last night that made a lot of sense to me. The game is just more tactical than I prefer out of my absolute top tier favorites.It was really rare to plan more than a turn or so ahead too concretely since you might at any time get a follow action, the next card you can draw might be better than anything currently in your hand, or new decrees or church tiles might come out that you really want to go for. Or maybe you're waiting for the next public building to come out but the player who you're expecting to build the available one isn't in any particular rush. There are a lot of things about the game that encourage you to be opportunistic, but then for me just optimizing a single turn isn't as exciting as formulating a long term plan and getting a bunch of stuff to line up perfectly.I think the obvious comparisons are to Gallerist and Kanban, and in the latter you really have to be careful about the sequence of actions you take because they all lead into each other in a really clever way and they have to be performed fairly precisely. In this game there are multiple competing sequences like that, I particularly like how the build up to building a public building is done at the same place where you build a store, and the best way to build up for a store is to tuck a treasury card and/or sell goods on ships. So you do have to be thoughtful about these sequences, but there are so many other things you can be doing and there's a bit more freedom to set yourself up for one of these actions and then finish them whenever is convenient.Gallerist I feel is similar to Lisboa in this way, where you have a lot of freedom in when you want to actually finish off the big point sequence you started. And I wonder now if that's similarly because of the variable nature of the follow actions. But Gallerist also loses a bit on this one since I think the sequence to scoring is a bit more straightforward, whereas in Lisboa it requires dealing with two interacting systems.And to be clear, just because I'm not so happy about the way this game handles the following (I think that's a decent chunk of what makes it so tactical) I'm not opposed to this kind of player driven stuff. But when I think about the games that I really love for their interesting player interaction (Brass, CO_2, The Great Zimbabwe) they have methods for influencing and incentivising the behavior you want out of the other players and/or have bigger rewards for predicting and taking advantage of your opponents' plans, which is what makes their interaction work so brilliantly. Here it sort of just feels like you're waiting until your opponents inevitably do something you can capitalize on, which is less interesting than the above games in that regard while also increasing the level of tactics vs strategy in the game.And here is where I need to make it clear that I do really enjoy this game quite a bit. I think I may seem critical because Vital is my favorite designer and so the expectations are higher. I could easily have seen this game entering my top 10, and as it is it's almost certainly hovering in the teens somewhere. Which is really good. It's definitely an interesting game, even just optimizing a turn or two still makes for a really interesting challenge as there are a lot of overlapping systems to consider.Wow, this got really long. I guess I just had a lot to say. I can't imagine anyone will bother reading the whole thing. Sorry. Anyway, if you're still here, check out the game, it's really cool.

posts.title: New Image for Love Letter
posts.text: Time Left for 2017 Support - I supported because… "if nobody did, _this place would go away_." - Laura Creighton (lacreighton) Our End-of-Year Geek support drive ends in 25 days ! It has been your support, financial and otherwise, that has allowed this site to become what it is today. Learn More

Sucking multicultural leeches have no teeth

Quisling politicians best be made aware that the
angry masses have pitchforks and flaming torches
and should wonder if they are coming up the hill
to get them. Under a stampede of plague
immigration, deregulation, privatization, and
globalist bullshit. Australia saw its countryside
raped, its cities fracture into third world
cesspits, and wealthy parasites fatten in their
walled estates. These are the new lunatics:
well-bribed public officials droning about how
diversity is the best thing about Australia;
screeching faggots riddled with incurable
arse-infections; gibbering multicultural idiots,
and subhuman locusts.

The genocidal anti-Australian agenda of multiculturalism

We are teaching our children that living in
Chinese-style "Stack and Pack" slums is the way of
the future - that we can't stop it happening
because of multicultural dogma. This is
sociological abuse and national cowardice. Yes,
multiculturalism is racist and genocidal. It is
important for us as Australians to admit how
futile and destructive multiculturalism has been
for Australia. Even the majority of immigrants
hate it intensely. Growth-mad politicians and
media drones parrot the drivel that diversity is
our strength. It is only the strength of those who
push this tripe. It is the strength of profiteers
seeking cheap labour, and of political, commercial
and ethnic interests.

Suppose your insane multicultural prayers aren't answered by your glorious globalist Moloch. What do you do then - sacrifice a white baby or two?

Urban land and energy prices are high and rising.
The price of an average house in 1973 was 3.5
years of median wage, with the land about 30% of
the price, now it is 7.5 years of median wage, 8-9
years in some cities, with land 75% of the price.
Australia's globalist government reckons the
answer to environmental problems is higher prices
of energy - not caring that Australia's economy
will go downhill because working class Australians
can't afford the new prices. We cannot find any
practical way to disperse our overpopulation from
the worsening putrid cities, so we must STOP
population growth in Australia. The growth mantra
chanted by both major political parties is
environmentally destructive.

A globalist dark age based on multicultural hysteria

We have seen how the property racketeering
industry provides selective statistics to support
the property market Ponzi scheme and advantage
their members, particularly developers. This is a
massive confidence trick on a whole nation. How
did the government address unaffordable housing,
to ensure that hard working Aussies can secure
basic shelter? By giving home owners grants which
did nothing apart from line the pockets of real
estate agents, property speculators and investors.
The sacred cow of mass immigration is part of some
deep and dark puzzle that confounds the experts,
and is supposedly benefiting most existing
Australians, despite evidence that it isn't. The
only safe assumption is that we are heading for
disaster.

How imported scab labour breaks unions and drives down wages

One of the lines that pro-Asian multiculturalists
trot out, is that Australia is part of Asia.
Australia is not a part of Asia. I've never heard
these suckholes say Australian Aborigines are
Asians. Australian society is a legacy of white
Europeans. Under globalist rule, human beings are
to be concentrated into "human settlement zones"
(Stalinist "Stack and Pack" slum cities). Those
globalists who exploit slaves and rape the earth
may live thousands of miles away from the areas
they destroy. We better not embrace the mangy old
pro-growth ethic that "more is better" - unless we
are insane or suicidal. Yes, I know the "Greens"
abandoned concerns about overpopulation some
decades ago, but we don't need to also be
globalist stooges.

The irrational belief that more imported scab labour is always better

Like a drug addict who has forsaken proper
nutrition for energy, the rotten new economy of
real estate growthism relies on an immigration fix
(and birth incentives to a lesser degree) for
energy. There is every reason to be angry about
population growth when it means struggling to live
in putrid Chinese-style "Stack and Pack" slums
that displace communities and wildlife. It is hard
to exaggerate just how awful this can be. Our
pathetic and corrupt nation, once a leader in so
many things, is reduced to supporting developers,
speculators, bankers and real estate Ponzi schemes
while importing cheap scab labour. What does this
say about Australian values?

The multicultural horror club

To get past this dialogue of the deaf, let me
state what most would agree is a reasonable
proposition about mass immigration: Every nation
has the right and the obligation to manage its
immigration to accord with its core values and
needs. An enormous surplus population of third
world misery will come to thee also, my awful
little multicultural drones. Did you think your
arses were covered? It's a grim thought, that
Australia is a nation of lemmings and spineless
jellyfish. The globalists highjacked the political
system, so there is no democracy. The average
citizen is no more than an economic share cropper
these days - if one can even find a paying job.
It's time to eat the rich. They shipped your jobs
overseas.

A national day of screeching multicultural hysteria

If Australians are racists because they reject
mass immigration, then many third world nations
must be hate mongers and racist because their
strict immigration policies allow very little
legal immigration and tolerate no illegal
immigration. Aussies followed the smell of
globalist deceit. It led them to the stinking
corruptions of multiculturalism and plague
immigration. Everything there is stripped bare by
"reforms" and "free market" forces. The great
multicultural plague immigration nightmare is
thrusting Australian life into a downward slide
toward third world poverty, congestion and chaos.
Only morons would "celebrate" the miseries of
systemic poverty or environmental destruction.

A globalist government and a bloated establishment you didn't elect

Fanatical devotion to national deconstruction
under multiculturalism, is the new globalist
plague. Plague immigration and cultural diversity
are major weapons and tools furthering this new
secular theology and infectious mental disease.
Under globalism, Aussies are working towards a
goal. That goal is their own replacement by
imported scab labour. Australians have
subordinated all their citizenship rights to
inimical alien agendas. Surrender is easier than
confrontation. Most immigrants don't focus on the
well-being of their new country any more than they
cared about the well-being of their old third
world pesthole. So don't expect toxic immigration
to enhance national solidarity any time soon.

Preparing "Stack and Pack" slums for the third world's unwanted breeders

Australians no longer ask questions of a moral and
ethical nature about saving their own nation and
its resources. That might anger the globalist
billionaires too much. The immoral "dog eat dog"
struggle must continue. I did not labour hard at
analyzing the train-wreck of Australian politics
simply to benefit the nongs. I don't care what
happens to the nongs. I write to inform those who
might help to avert a catastrophe while creating a
true national democracy. The multicultural
(homosexualized) weaklings must get over their
political correctness and stop sucking on mass
immigration. Plague immigration policy is best
when it only happens to some third world country
far away where we can't hear them scream.

The laughable vehemence of plague immigration policy

The entire political left buys into plague
immigration, year after relentless year, and
unsurprisingly, they lose more and more. Notice
what is never up for debate: The massive
displacement of the Australian populace by mass
immigration. The world is catastrophically
overpopulated, and moving the surplus population
fixes nothing. Something has to change, and change
must start somewhere. Let's start it here, in
Australia. Stop plague immigration and the baby
bonus. One great big, festering third world
pesthole Australia, with toxic immigration driven
unaffordable housing making it carnival time for
the plague landlords. An overdose of globalism
from spin merchants and breeding subhuman locusts.

It's a grim thought, that Australia must be culturally disintegrated so that the wealthy can greatly increase their unearned wealth

The globalist attempt to create a coffee-coloured
master race in Australia is a form of racial
genocide. The claimed desirability and necessity
for the multicultural obliteration of Australians
shows that whites cannot be tolerated. That
globalist stooges are so strangely desperate to
push extreme and expensive "projects" onto the
backs of ordinary citizens should remind us to
wonder for whose benefit we toil. Our tapeworm
"leaders" no longer fear us - perhaps they should.
The overpopulation boosting Vatican acts behind
the scenes, through a relatively small number of
Aussies who give the Church their loyalty for
reasons unrelated to religious practice, but
rather for advancement, power and privilege.

The rapidly approaching globalist end-game

Instead of abolishing the widespread poverty of
Australian citizens, our elected quislings chose
to massively import ethnic breeders and cheap scab
labour. This was done to advantage Jewish
billionaires and other parasitic plutocratic
filth. China's one child policy does more to
protect the climate than the rest of the world
combined. Australia must stop further nett
immigration and enforce a two child policy for a
stable population, with no religious group
exempted. Eternal bondage to plague immigration is
assured by the political establishment's vigorous
policy of real estate Ponzi scheme debt-bubble
inflation. Only the wealthy benefit from the
growth-fever that marks the end of a
disintegrating Australia.

So we find ourselves living in the plague immigration Ponzi scheme housing nightmare

If the immigration debate was framed in terms of
resource depletion and infrastructure, people
would focus on the point that the nation is "full"
in a social, economic and ecological sense. Never
underestimate human willingness to live the seven
deadly sins in varying degrees. Combine that with
the overriding instincts of self preservation, and
the need for procreation and human capacity for
destruction becomes and is boundless. Until the
plague immigration pigeons come home to roost and
shit on politicians or their estates, this dirty
travesty will continue. Nothing will be done to
curb plague immigration. Who asked for this shit
in the first place?

Most citizens don't want to know about the twisted minds of multicultural hypocrites

Unaffordable housing, rising costs, wage
restraint, unemployment, endless job-seeking,
random violence, unavailable medical and hospital
services, crowding and despair. This is globalism
operating in Australia - a cosy nest for ethnic
cuckoos. Globalists would like to teach citizens
how to toil long hours for less money, and how to
lose cultural and material control over their own
countries. Using a plague immigration recipe for
overpopulation, you too can cook your nation's
goose. The interwoven policies of deliberate
treason and pandemic immigration aim at the
subordination of Aussies and their interests to a
globalist pillage and conquest operation. Working
class desperation and social violence are just
icing on the cake.

Civilization was cut off at the knees by a political culture of bribery and corruption

In their quest to seize Australia's assets,
globalist chaos merchants tactically subverted the
schools and universities - whereby plague
immigration suddenly became sacred, holy, exalted
- no longer detrimental, destructive, deadly. The
multicultural confinement pods are opening. You
can feel the life giving national reality flooding
into the pods as the gases of globalist illusion
are recycled back into the original bullshit of
cultural diversity propaganda. Aussies are trapped
in their globalist cities of terror. As national
viability declines and plague immigration squeezes
everyone, Aussies are clutching at straws and
hanging on desperately. The "level playing field"
is only level for gangsters.

Pay homage to your evil globalist masters

While many have realized that unsustainable
population growth in Australia is courting
disaster, there are those who have not.
Idiotically, they argue we should continue our
unsustainable population growth indefinitely -
regardless of consequences. For decades, globalist
politicians and media drones refused to discuss
bulk immigration and branded those who tried, as
racist. If an election result swings on public
rage at being deceived about mass immigration, we
shall see them eat shit. Yes, we need to kill
plague immigration. Only some parasite sucking on
it or a complete fool would think otherwise. It is
easy for the wealthy to be apologists for mass
immigration as they don't have to live with the
rotten consequences.

Labor expressed "concerns" about plague immigration, but that is all forgotten now, and the property rackets are firing-up again

After years of multiculturalism, mass immigration
and globalization, many aliens now seem to think
they have an unlimited right to criticize our
society and its laws. We should deport them back
to their dictatorships and third world pestholes.
Many politicians are insane robots, running and
fetching for rich property developers and other
parasites. They have forgotten the "no" word, and
relentlessly clank ahead and over any public
opposition. They obey their masters, and that's
not us. Mass immigration is neatly sandwiched
between invasion and slavery. If the immigrants
prosper, it is invasion; if they are kept down and
exploited, it is slavery. Either way the local
gangsters and landed gentry will profit while
others lose.

An unsustainable cargo-cult creates a truth famine

Ignore the globalist propaganda about the great
social harmony and "vibrant" cultural diversity
claimed for plague immigration. Just replace the
bullshit with reality - it is all a swindle that
will leave Australians destitute in their own
country. Plague immigration is a rapidly
depreciating liability. The sooner that Aussies
ditch it, the sooner they get their country back.
Globalist exploitation of this country and
dispossesion by imported scab labour are dirty
worms in the national apple. Do this: 1. Open a
new file in your PC. 2. Name it "Plague
Immigration". 3. Send it to the Recycle Bin. 4.
Empty the Recycle Bin. 5. Your PC will ask: "Do
you really want to get rid of Plague Immigration?"
6. Firmly Click "Yes" 7. Feel better?

Plague immigration pushes our country ever deeper into ecological deficit

These gutless PC days, none dare to even allude
that restricting immigration can be part of open
debate. Billionaires have got our spineless
leaders by the nuts, and they can squeeze hard!
The memory of an Australia for Australians is
fading fast. Capitalism requires capital
formation, yet plague immigration and its real
estate Ponzi schemes cause huge debt-bubbles,
relentless capital destruction, the running down
of natural systems and resource depletion. Nothing
but insane greed and error. The psychopathology of
plague immigration displays no identifiable logic
or philosophical coherence. The multicultural hate
monkeys are very malignant and act as major agents
of ethnic subversion. How malignant is your
multicultural stupidity?

Our elected quislings fudged and defamed their own commissioned report (Long-Term Physical Implications of Net Overseas Migration)

Globalist economists argue that most Aussies will
have to accept lower living standards as a
privileged group of people enjoy the benefits of
downward pressure on wages created by high
immigration, which in turn keeps house prices and
rents rising. If you allow corrupt rezoning scams
to continue, you should prepare for the landed
gentry and property pimps calling for more
imported scab labour and the proliferation of
Chinese-style "Stack and Pack" slums in your
suburb. Ritual cruelty toward animals is an
integral part of many cultures we stupidly import.
Hysteria, insane violence, gang-rape and general
brutality are mere threads in the blood-soaked
multicultural tapestry of the stone-age cultures
we now coddle.

Liberal or Labor: Choosing crap or shit

The new paradigm of globalist corporate state
power, coupled with its bizarre ideology of
limitless progress and impossible happiness
through toxic immigration and multiculturalism,
has turned whole nations into monsters and zombie
states. Multicultural mass immigration bullshit:
the drivel of pre-digested cliches, and
platitudes; the parroted sound bites; the ad
hominem attacks; the third world ethnic strife;
and real estate Ponzi schemes that displace
legitimate economic activity. A generation ago, a
single manual worker wage provided a family with a
quality of life unimaginable on two professional
salaries today. Politicians and commentators
refuse to acknowledge that mass immigration
actually brought rapid impoverishment.

The burdens on native-born Aussies will rise to meet the needs of the plague immigration Ponzi scheme

Welcome to your new multicultural Australia. It
will certainly be increasingly diverse (chaotic),
jam-packed with "vibrant" ethnic strife, and rich
with hypocritical globalist dogs baying for white
Aussie blood and increased immigration. Do you
enjoy living in the bubble of bullshit coprophilic
multiculturalism made for you? That good old "wage
restraint" and unaffordable housing. A slice of
GST on top of the good things that your borrowed
money buys. It doesn't get better than this. When
a resentful ethnic hates you, that conveniently
defines you as a racist or xenophobe. Merely not
wanting plague immigration puts you beyond the
pale as some kind of genocidal nazi. There is no
simple way to clear such baseless defamation.

Cheap imported scab labour takes local jobs while locals are urged to "job seek" forever

Along with ethnic hate culture strife and disease,
we are importing poverty - typical plague
immigrants now consume more in services than they
pay in taxes. The rising price of goods and
services is overwhelming Aussie incomes. How could
we bring down the triumphalist arrogance of
multiculturalism and plague immigration ? There
would be terror in the universities if the
superannuation of refugee-hugging academics was
seized to pay ALL expenses of uninvited
immigrants. Maybe we are all equal, but the
"Yellow Australia" multicultural imported scab
labour policy makes imported misfits even more
equal. I think it is time we started deporting in
earnest. Hanging a few quislings for treason might
get the ball rolling.

When the multicultural legions of Hell obscure the truth

Any actual economic growth due to population
growth will end when our resources run out. By
then it will be too late to be thinking about
sustainability, and Australia will have starving
and angry ethnic hordes within its borders. This
largely infertile land cannot be flogged to
produce more crops, logging, woodchips,
agricultural products, and mining, without severe
environmental cost. Our tertiary education
institutions, including public ones, have become
back-door immigration entrances to Australia. A
sham export industry that is denying our own youth
jobs, course places, funded public education and
housing.

Defiled by a cabal of globalist quislings

Although the blatant plundering and fire-sales of
Australian and public national assets was
thorough, it was not slow. Degraded people always
assist their quisling governments to push them to
the sidelines. Spectator sport maintains mass
idiocy. So you don't have a stake in plague
immigration? That's because you are not a rich
parasite. The globalist rich will need
police-state terror to control public rage, once
the sheeple understand what is being done to them.
The corporate rats crawled out of the sewer: Urban
Taskforce Australia, which represents 85
companies, urged the government to resist pressure
from "anti-growth political forces" when it draws
up Australia's first population plan.

Globalist stooges will be in a dreadful pickle when we hold the treason trials

Nobody can blame the seething third world masses
for wishing to escape from their destroyed
countries to Australia and other Western
countries. What we can blame is our governments
for importing them as cheap scab labour and
desperate tenants. In 2050 a two per cent growth
of 50 million would be a million - the population
of Adelaide. Madness. You cannot build Adelaide
every year, no matter how competent the state
governments or how aggressive the property
developers. Boosting plague immigration and
engaging in desperate and greedy property
speculation, is a sure recipe for human misery and
national collapse if continued. Any economic
growth will be jobless growth, and only wealthy
parasites will benefit.

To further enrich property parasites

It cannot be called democracy when our billionaire
friendly politicians carefully conceal their
intentions about increasing mass immigration, as
they approach an election. It is third world
overpopulation by stealth. Too many "refugees"
that politicians are keen to "embrace" and foster,
turn vicious when they discover they can't have
everything their own beastly way. It is time do
the exact opposite of everything our quisling
"leaders" expect us to do. Former Treasury
Secretary Ken Henry said something in his recent
farewell speech that probably shocked the
immigrationist idiots and multicultural muppets.
He said that no more than 15 million people is a
sustainable population for Australia.

posts.text: Re: Is it worth for solo only ? kelann08 wrote: Which ones? This sounded "off" to me so I went back to the appendix and reread the abilities provided by various embassies. Outside of the one that allows you to ignore the fee, which I tangentially mentioned, what embassy is "impossible to use" without other players? By my look, none of them, but I may have missed something. I didn't say the embassies were impossible to use I said a big part of what those embassies offer is impossible to use. I am referring in particular to the Labourer and Alchemists... each of them have a 'special ambassador' that is redundant in the solo game (the rules for which are not detailed there in the almanac, but on page 19 of the rule book.) Quote: Everything in this rule book applies to all numbers of players. Frankly, I expect a little bit more, considering there are a number of features of the game that are redundant in solo (some of the market cards also offer a take starting player option and that particular market card will be weaker than the others, that's another example, and then there's the hex that let's you take starting player and one clay. I really don't think it's too much to expect a little attention to these things, and more gravely, to the embassies, if they want to sell it as 1-4. Quote: I never found the cards swingy. In what was is that the case for you? Personally, I found that A) it's a lot of work to play a card and B) they're often over costed compared to doing something comparably on the board. You have to jump through a number of hoops to make them superior in value (like having an institute). It sounds like you prefer to mosty just skip the cards, is that right? Or just take one now and again if it happens to come your way? In which case, fair enough, you wouldn't notice much swinginess!! But if you do go the route of a card strategy in solo (and build an institute, etc) then the outcome of your game is very dependent on which cards you happen to see.

thread.title: Reply: Gloomhaven:: General:: Re: Gloomhaven vs. D&D?
thread.title_full: Reply: Gloomhaven:: General:: Re: Gloomhaven vs. D&D?

posts.author: DeS_Tructive
posts.title: Reply: Gloomhaven:: General:: Re: Gloomhaven vs. D&D?
posts.text: ( mwonham ) United Kingdom The ONLY similarity between them is the fantasy setting, weird monsters and magic. Gloomhaven is a board game, with a rule book that controls what happens. Players have the ability to work within those constrained rules. The role-playing aspect is limited in that the scenarios and events are themselves highly constrained. D&D has a similar setting theme, and so on. But it's free-form in that every scenario and engagement is acted out, improvised and played by both the DM and the players. The monsters in D&D are more 'intelligent' in that the DM will make decisions for them. So in Gloomhaven, the rules dictate how a monster targets an enemy and moves. (And for what it's worth many of the discussions on this board around movement seem to me to be people trying to give monsters more intelligence than the designer felt could be accomodated sensibly without a DM). In D&D the DM does that. If he/she wants the kobolds to hang-back and wait for the goblins to get slaughtered, that's what they'll do. In GH they're not so tactically astute.Games like Pathfinder (D&D clone) also relate to GH in the use of 'pawns'. The vendors sell playmats, figures, etc., and the combat system (for 50 years) has been based on a 1" grid and everything in those games flows from that. You don't need figures to play D&D/Pathfinder/etc, but it sure helps. And that's where people may be getting confused. THe use of the physical mat/map in the role-playing games helps to understand what's happening and the possibilities. In GH the board makes the rules.Don't conflate the two games. Thematically similar, but hugely different in the experience, the gameplay and so on. Both very rewarding.

thread.title: Reply: Recommendations:: Re: Give me one good game that will keep us busy for a year
thread.title_full: Reply: Recommendations:: Re: Give me one good game that will keep us busy for a year

posts.author: entwife
posts.title: Reply: Recommendations:: Re: Give me one good game that will keep us busy for a year
posts.text: DeerfieldWisconsin The stuff I'd recommend is probably a bit heavier or too involved than what you want. I'm not going to give one, but several so you can see how my recommendations don't match the level of games yo seem to enjoy at all: Roads & Boats An interesting gather and process resource VP game. Here you only own that which is on your wooden transport meeples, and any buildings you make or resources produced by them are public domain. Don't worry, you can build walls if you want. In the base game, your goal is to eventually mine gold, process that gold into coins, then merge those coins with paper to make stock certificates (these three are what earn you VP at the end of the game). Like many Splotter games, players influence the game length. In this case, you spend resources to add bricks to a wonder; and then when enough bricks are added the game ends. Oh, and the wonder is another source of VP. The expansion & Cetera adds more mechanisms and ways to score VP.It can be played for a year because it is scenario driven with many different maps made from the modular tile. A logistics game that requires a lot of thinking and planning, and a costly one to get. I see the base game at about $200 and the expansion at around $50 - which is about a 100% or so markup over the original retail price, so it really isn't that big of a used game markup. Don't know if it will be reprinted any time soon. However, $250 for a game that you'll play for a year over and over isn't really all that bad - and its cheaper than getting on most Fantasy Flight Games expansion treadmills for LCGS or minis games. Leaving Earth I call it "Roads & Boats in Space" because this game is all about mission planning to get VP. Each player controls a historical space agency, gets a fixed annual budget, and uses that budget to buy tech/buy hardware/perfect hardware/hire anstronauts to try to complete mission goals that are randomly selected decks. The game is set 1956 to 1976 and there is some math involved, but the player aids let you avoid having to do too much math (more of "each rocket can boost this much mass, so I have to get a total mass of this there... which means I need to use these many of this type of rocket to get that there and... oh my that's expensive; maybe I should buy rendezvous technology to make it easier and less risky...").The base game has the worlds of Earth, The Moon, Venus, Mars with Phobos, and Ceres; and it also now includes the Mercury mini-expansion. Play base game first, trust me on this. Then add Mercury.The first expansion is Outer Planets. This adds the gas and ice giants; Jupiter and 4 moons, Saturn and 2 moons, Neptune, Uranus. Some new tech is added to handle sending probes out there.The second expansion is Stations and it adds a lot of awesome stuff. Reusable rockets, rovers, space station modules, ground habitats, new ways for handling exploring locations, and much more.The bad news is you must order direct from Luminaris Group's webpage and there may be a delay on shipping no copies are on hand. The up side is that the total cost of the game is $45 + $40 + $35 or $120 for all 3 expansions, and they will keep you busy for a year. High Frontier 3E Phil Eklund of Sierra Madre Games is a literal rocket scientist, and this his his game of near future space exploration. The game seems daunting at first, but you have a very simple base game with many modules to add in (for freighters, warfare and politics, colonists, auxiliary components in building your spacecraft, and so on). 3E was a horrible kickstarter to suffer through, and the game components were no better than normal Sierra Madre Games titles... well, almost. The board is beautiful. 12" x 12" panels that let you have a 1.5' x 2' board for the solar system, a 1.5' x 2' board for early interstellar expansion, and flip those boards and you have a massive mounted 2' x 3' board of the system that is good for aging eyes.Sadly, this is out of print, so you are looking at $200-$300 (which isn't uncommon for OOP Sierra Madre Games or Splotter titles), but in this case it is well worth it. 2E original MSRP was something like $80 for the game and expansion plus $40 for the zazzle map for interstellar plus $40 for the poster map of the base game system (the original game had more standard letter sized panels for its board also). Essentially, $200 is a fair market price compared to the retail components - and when kickstarted it was only $70 so that was a steal on the price for such a low volume print run (when you play niche games like wargames, you are used to high prices). Pax Pamir or Pax Renaissance or even Pax Porfiriana Yup, more Sierra Madre Games stuff. Some are out of print, some aren't. These small box games (The Grizzled sized boxes or 50% larger) are full games in a box. You get a good amount of cards but only use a subset for each. The rules are daunting due to the semi-archaic way that Phil Eklund writes, and because he believes in making it more useful when playing (common game rules are in a glossary of terms to quickly look up, so you have to constantly flip to the back of the book when reading it to learn... which means you need to know the typographical cues on when a term is in the back of the book to look up).At the core of these games is the market and victory triggering cards. The market is two rows with a cost to buy cards deeper in, and then you build a tableau off of these cards. Victory triggers either trigger a check for the current of 4 cards revealed to see if someone wins early or to activate a victory check card ( Pax Renaissance ). This makes the strategies subtle, and when combined with using a small subset of overall cards you have high replay value.Costs for acquiring these games vary, as some are out of print. I'd gladly pay $100 for Pax Pamir , it is a wonderful game. Still, costs are all over the board as these go out of print longer and longer.Related games that will have a kickstarter in January or February are Neanderthal and Greenland . Also, Bios Genesis and Bios Megafauna 2E (shipping in January/February) a set of games that you can play to simulate life evolving from the formation of earth to just post Chicxulub impact - and plans to work on a third game in the series are underway. However, these sets of games don't have quite the replay value as the Pax series; they might not keep you engaged for a full year.

posts.text: 26. Board Game: Stuffed Fables [Average Rating:8.15 Unranked] Daniel Atorf GermanyKarlsruhe This game's description really got me (no wonder, as I already like Mice and Mystics ). I am very curious about the story book and I just love the overall theme and world described.Sadly weren't able to play the prototype at Essen but I'm looking forward to the release. Tags: co-op; stuffies save child; narrative driven; story book; colored dice; dice bag Quote: Stuffed Fables is an unusual adventure game in which players take on the roles of brave stuffies seeking to save the child they love from a scheming, evil mastermind . Make daring melee attacks, leap across conveyor belts, or even steer a racing wagon down a peril-filled hill.Stuffed Fables delivers a thrilling narrative driven by player choices . Players explore a world of wonder and danger, unlocking curious discoveries. The chapters of Stuffed Fables explore the many milestones of a child’s life , creating a memorable tale ideal for families, as well as groups of adults who haven’t forgotten their childlike sense of wonder.Each adventure in Stuffed Fables takes place over several pages of the immersive Storybook . The book opens flat onto the table to reveal a colorful map or other illustration central to playing the game, with choices, story, and special rules on the opposite page.On her turn, a player draws 5 dice from the bag . The colors of the dice drawn determine the types of actions and options available to the player. As turns go by, black dice are also drawn, and after enough appear, minions emerge or attack, and the dice bag is reset!White dice can re-stuff stuffies injured in battle. Red dice perform melee attacks while green dice perform ranged attacks. Yellow dice search while blue dice are used for special actions and purple dice can be used as any color. Most dice can always find a strategic use, including moving, using items, or contributing to group tasks. Store dice for later, combine dice for stronger actions or use them one-at-a-time for multiple activations.Players can encourage each other by sharing dice or their precious stuffing . In addition to fighting minions, each page of the storybook offers numerous points of interest, charming characters to interact or trade with, as well as many unusual challenges. And each page is but one chapter that folds into a branching, overarching story with a multitude of items and a special discovery deck full of surprises.Stuffed Fables is a StoryBoard Game – an exciting new product line from Plaid Hat Games. In a StoryBoard Game all of the action takes place in the unique storybook – a book that acts as your rules reference, story guide, and game board, all in one!

thread.title: Who Is More Likely to Default on Student Loans?
thread.title_full: Who Is More Likely to Default on Student Loans?

posts.author: Guest Author
posts.title: Who Is More Likely to Default on Student Loans?
posts.text:
Who Is More Likely to Default on Student Loans? December 7, 2017 5:00am by Guest Author Who Is More Likely to Default on Student Loans? Rajashri Chakrabarti, Nicole Gorton, Michelle Jiang, and Wilbert van der Klaauw Liberty Street Economics November 20, 2017 



This post seeks to understand how educational characteristics (school type and selectivity, graduation status, major) and family background relate to the incidence of student loan default. Student indebtedness has grown substantially , increasing by 170 percent between 2006 and 2016. In addition, the fraction of students who default on those loans has grown considerably. Of students who left college in 2010 and 2011, 28 percent defaulted on their student loans within five years, compared with 19 percent of those who left school in 2005 and 2006. Since defaulting on student loans can have serious consequences for credit scores and, by extension, the ability to purchase a home and take out other loans, it’s critical to understand how college and family characteristics correspond to default rates. 
To better understand the determinants of student loan default , we ask the following questions in this blog post: Do default rates differ by college type? How do default rates of dropouts compare to those of graduates, and does this relationship vary by degree program? Does default vary with college major? Does college selectivity (defined below) matter for this relationship, and for student loan default more generally? Are students from less advantaged backgrounds more likely to default than students from more advantaged backgrounds? 
To answer these questions, we utilize a unique data set that matches the New York Fed Consumer Credit Panel (CCP), based on Equifax data, to National Student Clearinghouse (NSC) education data, allowing us to track student debt and educational attainment over time for a representative sample of young adults. Throughout this discussion, it is important to note that our analysis is descriptive and, while suggestive, does not necessarily imply causation. For example, our results could partially reflect differences in the backgrounds and financial means of students who choose to attend various colleges. 
As in our previous work with this data set , we focus on individuals born between 1980 and 1986 and track their college attendance and student loan default status by age. In this post, since we focus on determinants of student loan default, we limit our sample to students who took out student debt to finance their education. We focus on the characteristics associated with the highest degree-granting institution a student attended before age twenty-seven. We study default rates by age: out of all student loan holders in the 1980–86 birth cohorts, what fraction of people of a given age has defaulted on at least one of their student loans? 
To examine differences in default rates by college type , we classify student debt holders by the type of college attended: did they attend a public, private not-for-profit, or private for-profit college, and was it a two-year institution or a four-year institution? 
As seen in the chart below, students who attended private for-profit institutions have the highest default rates after their mid-twenties (shown in the blue lines). In contrast, at every age, four-year private not-for-profit students—the solid gold line—have the lowest default rates. For every college type (public, not-for-profit and for-profit), two-year students (dashed lines) have higher default rates than four-year students (solid lines). While this largely reflects the higher earnings prospects enjoyed by four-year students, it also partly reflects the earlier start of the loan repayment period for two-year students and inherent differences between two- and four-year students. 
Interestingly, though the difference in default rates between two- and four-year private college students is not large (less than 5 percentage points at age thirty-three), this is not the case for public college students. Default rates for community college (two-year public college) students are nearly 25 percentage points higher than those for their counterparts in four-year public colleges. The chart below also shows that while for-profit students have the highest default rates, the default rates of community college students are not too different from those of for-profit students (36 percent versus 42 percent for two-year and 39 percent for four-year for-profit students, respectively, at age thirty‑three). 
The next chart categorizes student debt holders by graduation status as well as by degree program. (Throughout this discussion, “bachelor’s” and “bachelor’s or higher” refer interchangeably to those with bachelor’s or higher-level degrees.) Regardless of degree program, dropouts have higher default rates at every age than graduates—likely because graduates enjoy the labor market benefits of having earned a degree, making it easier for them to find better jobs and repay their loans. However, among dropouts, the default comparison between associate and bachelor’s degree students changes over time. Bachelor-seeking students who did not graduate default at nearly the same rate as dropouts in associate programs until age twenty-nine, when the associate default rate climbs substantially, surpassing that of bachelor’s students. 
Among graduates, those with associate degrees default at higher rates than those with bachelor’s degrees since their early twenties; the difference by age thirty-three is much larger among graduates (13 percentage points) than among dropouts (4 percentage points). This chart strongly suggests that graduation markedly reduces defaults, and the bachelor’s degree premium (as far as defaults are concerned) is considerably greater among graduates than dropouts. To put these numbers in perspective, 53 percent of debt holders graduate and 90 percent of those people earn a bachelor’s degree. Among loan holders who drop out, 28 percent were enrolled in an associate program. 
In the next chart, we categorize student loan holders by the selectivity of the college they attended and by the major they pursued. Using Barron’s Profile of American Colleges (2001) ranking of college competitiveness, we classify four-year colleges into two categories: “selective” (colleges ranked “competitive” or above by Barron’s ) and “nonselective.” In addition, we classify students into one of four fields, based on their major: “Arts and Humanities” (majors such as languages, sociology, theater), “Business and Law” (economics, legal studies, management), “STEM” (science, technology, engineering, mathematics), and “Vocational” (aviation, cosmetology, welding). 
In analysis not reported here, we find that Arts majors have the highest overall default rates, while STEM majors default at the lowest rates. Both Business and Vocational majors default at higher rates than STEM majors, but at rates closer in magnitude to STEM majors than to Arts majors. Next, we separate students not only by major, but also by school selectivity; the chart below presents patterns at age thirty-three. We find that students attending nonselective colleges have higher default rates no matter what they study. Arts majors have the highest default rates regardless of college selectivity, but major matters much more among students at nonselective colleges: the gap in default rates between the best performing major and worst performing major is much smaller (3 percentage points by age thirty-three) among students at selective colleges than among students at nonselective colleges (8 percentage points by age thirty‑three). 
Next, to analyze differences with respect to family background, we categorize individuals according to the average 2010 income in the zip code in which they resided at the youngest age we observe them in our data. We divide the panel between individuals from areas with an average income above $55,000 and those from areas with an average income below $55,000 (as measured in 2010). In analysis not reported here, we found that students from less advantaged family backgrounds have higher default rates. To understand this relationship, we investigate whether this correlation differs by college type. 
In the chart below, we group debt holders by our family background measure, as well as by college type. We find that within each college type, students from less-advantaged backgrounds have higher default rates than their peers from a more-advantaged background. There is a nearly 30 percentage point difference in default rates between the group with the highest default rates (private for-profit students from less advantaged backgrounds) and the group with the lowest default rates (private not-for-profit students from more advantaged backgrounds). However, public college students from more advantaged backgrounds default at nearly the same rate as private not-for-profit students from less advantaged backgrounds (about 20 percent by age thirty-three). As before, at every age, for-profit students have the highest default rates, and students from less advantaged backgrounds attending for-profit colleges default at an even higher rate. 
These stark differences in default rates with respect to school type, graduation status, college selectivity, major, and family background continue to hold even when we look at conditional correlations in a simple regression framework, introducing all these variables simultaneously. Attending a four-year private for-profit college correlates most strongly with increasing default, while dropping out is the second strongest predictor of default. These patterns are consistent with our finding that students from different educational and family backgrounds experience different returns on their academic investments . Our data show that students who drop out before earning a degree, enroll in an associate degree program as opposed to a bachelor’s degree program, major in the arts, attend a for-profit institution, community college or non-selective college, or come from a less advantaged family background are more likely to default by their late twenties compared to their peers. This represents preliminary evidence that later life outcomes—for example, the ability to buy a home and maintain a strong credit score—may vary widely among student loan holders based on their educational choices and backgrounds. 
Chart data

thread.title: John Keenan: SIPP/SSAS limitation of liability clauses explained
thread.title_full: John Keenan: SIPP/SSAS limitation of liability clauses explained

posts.author: Jenna Towler
posts.title: John Keenan: SIPP/SSAS limitation of liability clauses explained
posts.text:
Technical John Keenan: SIPP/SSAS limitation of liability clauses explained John Keenan strongly recommends a limitation of liability clause is included in every lease linked to to SIPP and SSAS pensions. Here's why... By - Dec 7, 2017 
When a small self-administered scheme (SSAS) or self-invested personal pension (SIPP) purchases a commercial property the requirement for a limitation of liability clause within the subsequent lease between new owners and tenant should be put on the table at the earliest possible juncture. 
This clause is as far removed from its ‘LOL’ acronym (used in text speak) as it could be, and in our experience not flagging it at the earliest opportunity can cause real problems down the line. 
At its worst, it can waste thousands of pounds of valuable pension scheme funds. Certainly no LOL matter. 
So what is it and what does it do? 
A limitation of liability is a clause inserted within a lease that ensures if any liability arises, then it will be restricted to the value of the individual’s pension scheme funds. It should be clearly flagged within a lease and an example of the typical wording would be: 
“ It is hereby agreed by the parties hereto that the liability of ABC Pension Trustees shall not exceed the net value of the assets within its control in THE A SMITH SIPP and that save for that the TENANT shall not have any claim whatsoever against ABC Pension Trustees.” 
This protects both the professional trustees and, where they are a trustee, the member in their individual capacity. By ring-fencing liability to the assets of the SIPP member’s fund that is making the investment, it also ensures that the assets of other pension trust members are not exposed where they are all held under one trust. 
When is it required? 
I would strongly recommend that the limitation of liability clause is included in every lease. 
This would include agreements with the freeholder (when purchasing long leasehold) or the tenant (when granting a lease as a freeholder or long leaseholder). 
In my experience persuading the other party to accept this requirement usually falls into one of two categories; either completely straightforward or very complicated, there doesn’t seem to be many that fall in-between. 
A straightforward example might be when a SSAS or SIPP is purchasing and leasing the property to a connected party. 
In these circumstances it won’t usually cause a problem, as while the owner-tenant must act independently (wearing the two hats of pension scheme and tenant), there is no commercial favour being granted and both parties benefit as it is in their interests to have their pension scheme assets protected. 
In our experience, the lawyers representing both parties will agree to the clause and the lease will be executed. 
Where it becomes complicated is when a property is being purchased subject to an existing lease already being in place. In these circumstances, you are asking an existing tenant to vary the terms of the lease to include the limitation of liability clause. 
While in practice it should not cause them any concerns, you are still beholden upon them acceding to the request and in our experience where the tenant is someone like a large national supermarket, betting chain or retail outlet, they have standard leases with all their landlords and can be unwilling to give any local or specific flexibility. 
An absolute must 
The limitation of liability clause is a pre-requisite for most SSAS and SIPP providers and, taking us back to the first point, it must be raised at the outset otherwise you run the risk of a commercial property purchase costing thousands of pounds in legal fees only to get to a point where the SSAS or SIPP realises it cannot proceed with a transaction because the tenant will simply not agree to the clause. 
We have thousands of SSAS and SIPP commercial properties within our portfolio and have purchased hundreds this year, all of which will have the limitation of liability clause. It should not be a problem as long as it is explained clearly and at the right time. 
Oh, and assuming the tenant is reasonable, which they always are, LOL! 
John Keenan is corporate development manager at Xafinity SIPP and SSAS TAGS

posts.text: California TK313 wrote: I'm building a set of the game from PDF, and I miss just one piece of info. How many stacking tiles of each color should there be in the 100-piece set? What you need depends on how many ships you're playing with. in theory, three black tiles per ship is good, in case you have a ship at negative and want to use absolute stacks under segment future position marker and the end-of-turn marker. However, it's unlikely that so many ships will be at a negative altitude that you'll need that many tiles.Ken and I both recommend updating the location of the end of turn marker so keep it an "8 segments in the future" marker. Much more useful.

thread.title: Reply: Flamme Rouge:: Reviews:: Re: Flamme Rouge: A Multilingual (ha!) Review
thread.title_full: Reply: Flamme Rouge:: Reviews:: Re: Flamme Rouge: A Multilingual (ha!) Review

posts.author: moorwild
posts.title: Reply: Flamme Rouge:: Reviews:: Re: Flamme Rouge: A Multilingual (ha!) Review
posts.text: - En Garde (Knizia)It will be no surprise to my gentle readers that I’m a big fan of Bucket #3. (For the record, I’d throw Snow Tails , Downforce and Royal Turf into de derde emmer – Dutch for “the third bucket”. I’m a veritable linguist today.)But a great sports game experience can come from any of the three types – one of my favorite gaming memories is playing Dynasty League Baseball and Pizza Box Football on the same night with a crew of sports/board game fans at Gulf Games.Still, when I’m choosing a sports game to play, more often than not I’ll choose something simple yet evocative… like Flamme Rouge . “I Want To Ride My Bicycle, I Want To Ride My Bike…” One of the first games I bought from directly from Germany back in the late ‘90s was the 1992 Spiel des Jahres winner, Um Reifenbreite (which loosely translates as “By the Width of a Tire”).The description on The Game Cabinet (which was the landing page for board game geeks before BGG appeared) had me practically salivating… so I ponied up the big bucks to have the team from Funagain Games scour the used game stalls at Essen to find me a copy. And, true to their word, they did.Um Reifenbreite uses a combination of roll’n’move with card play (to simulate pushes to the front or climbing ability) along with a random event card to evoke the feel of team cycling. Each player has four cyclists and they can draft off other riders as they race around the board. The board design allows for four different races (two shorter, two longer) that can be chained together into a series of stages for a “ Tour de Spelrum ”. (The last phrase – “Tour de Game Room” – is brought to you by the mashup of French & Swedish – let’s call it Swench. Or Frendish. You pick.)I have few complaints about Um Reifenbreite – it’s been in my top 20 games for nearly two decades. Probably my own concern is how difficult it is to get to the table – due in part to the cartoonish French art style and the roll’n’move nature of the game. “Whenever I see an adult on a bicycle, I do not despair for the human race.” Fast forward to Essen 2016… and the nice folks from Lautapelit.fi in Finland released Flamme Rouge . (Ok, kids, say Terveydeksi ! to our Nordic friends…) Seeing pictures (and positive reviews) from the folks across the briny blue just made me want to play Um Reifenbreite again.That is, until I had the opportunity to play Flamme Rouge – and suddenly all of the “thumbs up” noise began to make sense.The game itself is a model of streamlined design – the rules only take four pages, and that includes the cover & components list. Players start by choosing a track from a selection of six different tracks and then build it in the center of the table. (You can, of course, build it on the edge of the table… heck, march to the beat of a different drummer. But if you’re playing at my house, it goes in the center of the table.) The track itself is a series of double-sided straights, gentle curves and right angle curves.After placing their two riders in the starting grid, the race begins. Players have two decks of cards, one for each racer – a rouleur (I call him “mountain guy”) and a sprinter. Simultaneously, players choose one of their two decks and draw a hand of four movement cards – then they choose one and place the other three under that deck face up. Then the player does the same with the other deck, leaving them with two cards ready to play.When all players are ready, they turn over their cards and resolve movement in order from the front to the back of the racers. Cyclists may move through other riders but cannot stop on a full space (one with two riders). After all the riders have moved, drafting is calculated, starting at the back of the pack and moving forward – any group of cyclists who have exactly one space between them and the next group slide up a space to close the gap. When all movement and drafting are taken care of, the lead cyclists in each group have to take an exhaustion card and add it to their discards at the bottom of your deck.There are a couple of twists – there is no drafting when going uphill (and your maximum speed is 5). By the same token, your minimum speed if you start on a downhill slope is 5, regardless of which card you play.The first rider to cross the finish line wins the game for his team. If multiple riders cross in the same turn, the one who goes the farthest first wins. “Nothing compares to the simple pleasure of riding a bike.” As I finish typing up this description, I’m reminded of one of the many reasons I love this game: it is unbelievably easy to teach. While folks have varied in their ability to figure out winning tactics, no one has come away frustrated that the game was too difficult to comprehend.Another element I love is the way in which these simple rules create a game that “feels” like team cycling. I’ll admit I was skeptical – what with my deep love for Um Reifenbreite – about a team cycling game with only two cyclists… but much like StreetSoccer’s five player game of fußball, Flamme Rouge manages to capture the ethos without getting bogged down by fleshing out a full cycling team. There are attempts to break from the pack, lagging to conserve energy, blocking to hold back leaders, slow starts, fast starts, breakdowns due to exhaustion… it’s all there. Flamme Rouge is also a quick game – once everyone has a game under their collective belts, races should clock in at about 30 minutes. There is an unofficial iOS app that allows groups to create stage race series if you want to link races together – but the game works just fine playing stand-alone races. “Life is like a 10-speed bicycle. Most of us have gears we never use.” Flamme Rouge is best with 4 players, though it works very well with 3. Two players is fine – but you really need more riders on the track to get the full feel of the game.The Peloton expansion was released last month at Essen and it adds the ability to play with 5 or 6 players… something I’m looking forward to greatly. (Stronghold Games will be bringing the expansion over in early 2018.)We’ve played all of the official track configurations in the game – and the only one we’re unlikely to play again is La Haut Montagne. (Reason: it ends with an uphill climb – which is would be fine in a stage race situation but is a little anti-climactic when you’re playing one-off races.) “Learn to ride a bicycle. You will not regret it if you live.” While Flamme Rouge has not replaced Um Reifenbreite in my collection, it has hit the table over and over throughout 2017. The short playing time is certainly a factor – and as we get to add the Peloton expansion, it will be suitable for a wider variety of player counts. So with the attractive production (we love the cyclist pawns), the variable tracks, the easy-to-learn rules and the excellent fit between theme and gameplay, this is a winner – a maillot jaune . (I couldn’t end this review without one more linguistic bon mot – ok, make it two.) Quote References (in order of appearance) Schoolhouse Rock, “3 is a Magic Number”Queen, “Bicycle Race”

The powerful Palestinian Islamist group Hamas called on Thursday for a new uprising against Israel after US President Donald Trump's recognition of Jerusalem as the Israeli capital.

The "Global Egg and Poultry Category - Procurement Market Intelligence Report" report has been added to Research and Markets' offering. 
Technological advances have led to an increased number of birds per farmer/worker, leading to higher outputs and facilitating the replacement of labor as the industry is grappling with a shortage of skilled labor. Advances in breeding have resulted in improvements in animal size, growth rate, fecundity, and uniformity, leading to higher outputs. Data collection technologies for analysis of flock, in-shed sensors for monitoring production data, and farm software for reducing GHG emissions are some of the other innovations aiding suppliers to improve the production processes. 
The report provides actionable insights to improve source-to-contract cycle performance in the Global Egg and Poultry Market. It helps sourcing professionals formulate better category strategies, enhance savings, understand supplier and market challenges, and implement sourcing best practices. 
This report, Global Egg and Poultry Market, provides up-to-date information about market shifts and potential risks, as well as in-depth knowledge of products and services, which can help in planning and in executing category management activities. It focuses on the cost-saving aspects of procurement and on providing insights that can lead to optimization of category spend. 
Key questions answered in this report 
What are the market dynamics? What are the key market trends? What are the category growth drivers? What are the constraints to category growth? Who are the suppliers in this market? posts.title: 60. T'was The Challenge Before Christmas
posts.text:
T'was the challenge before Christmas, when all through craft room, Everything was frantic, as Christmas was coming too soon!

Hello dear crafty chums, I hope you are well and not too frantic! I thought it would be fun to take any element from the poem, A Visit from St. Nicholas. It is a story that my mum would read to me at the run up to Christmas and I could probably recite from memory! I was slightly concerned  that the original poem would be too long so, with great pains, I cut some of the verses. I hope you have a wonderful Christmas!

"'Twas the night before Christmas, when all through the house  
Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse;  
The stockings were hung by the chimney with care,  
In hopes that St. Nicholas soon would be there;  

The moon on the breast of the new-fallen snow,  
Gave a lustre of midday to objects below,  
When what to my wondering eyes did appear,  
But a miniature sleigh and eight tiny rein-deer,  

With a little old driver so lively and quick,  
I knew in a moment he must be St. Nick.  

He was dressed all in fur, from his head to his foot,  
And his clothes were all tarnished with ashes and soot;  
A bundle of toys he had flung on his back,  
And he looked like a pedler just opening his pack.  

He spoke not a word, but went straight to his work,  
And filled all the stockings; then turned with a jerk,  
And laying his finger aside of his nose,  
And giving a nod, up the chimney he rose;  

But I heard him exclaim, ere he drove out of sight—  
“Happy Christmas to all, and to all a good night!”"

posts.text: If you've always dreamed of stepping onto the set of Outlander, Starz and Mashable have just the ticket: an exclusive deleted scene from Season 3, episode 11, filmed with 360 degree cameras to allow you to explore every inch of the Artemis — the gorgeous full-scale ship that's currently carrying Claire and Jamie Fraser to Jamaica. Even better, you get a guided tour from Caitriona Balfe and Sam Heughan, who are happy to channel their inner pirates while showing off the sprawling South Afric.. Advertisement
